Award.AwardTitle: Few Level Models in Atomic Radiation Theory
Award.AbstractNarration:
Two principal projects will be undertaken. They both engage modern photon-atom theory, and are designed to increase understanding of advanced methods of optical communication. In one case the principal issue is using light to influence light. A prime application would be to stop a light pulse by coherent absorption in a specific vapor, and later using a second pulse to retrieve it for use. In the other case, the goal is to show how to engage the quantum principle of entanglement in a purely non-quantum context, where light fields are projected to be feasible carriers of classical entanglement.

The consequences and benefits of the research to be done are numerous, and include advances in speed and reliability of communication systems, potentially incorporating novel aspects of communication security. The skills acquired by the PhD students who will work on the two projects are expected to be valuable in both industrial and governmental development work following their graduation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
An important goal of this Project was to make use of the research in more than one way.  We anticipated that the scientific findings would have substantial value in themselves, but we expected that the ongoing activity could have broader benefits as well. Among these are the development of resources long overlooked, but of great potential value to society and science. One is the increasing participation of under-represented population groups. In a one-PI Project it is not possible to take big steps in this direction, but small steps also count. This Project has been fortunate to be able to reach out and bring young women into the productive mainstream of modern physics. In the period reported here a very creative PhD student, Elizabeth Groves, finished her degree work in mathematical quantum optics. Her published papers and PhD thesis made a notable advance in application of Darboux theory to a complex two-pulse information control process. Its value has already been established, as the foundation for two published papers by a succeeding student. We have also benefited from the work of PhD student Bethany Little, who initiated the lab test of the Project's theoretical work on classical entanglement. This has resulted in a conference presentation by Bethany, and co-authorship of a very challenging paper in Optica.


One of two main research goals of this NSF Project was to use the theory of electromagnetism to exploit properties of ordinary non-quantum light in ways not previously considered feasible. This was possible to do because ordinary light has also been found to contain coherent photonic properties recognized only in quantum light until very recently. These properties are now known as hidden classical coherences, and a prime example is a new form of light polarization. It becomes observable when ordinary polarization is suppressed by selective projections. We showed that when three degrees of freedom are available in a light beam, as is usually the case, transfers of hidden coherence among the three can be done by exploiting the new polarization. The theory that we developed led to proof-of-principle experimental work, which confirmed the capabilities suggested by the theoretical work. The combination of the theoretical finding and the experimental design that it led to can be expected to have future implications for application to communication technology.


The other main research goal of this NSF Project was to develop an analytic (non-numerical) model to describe the transmission of two different-color light pulses through extended media. The point of attack was to consider the case when the two frequencies of the light beams match transition frequencies offered by the transmission medium (modeled as having appropriate two-level and three-level resonances). The pulses were assumed sufficiently short (in the 100 femtosecond range) to ignore relaxation effects in the medium, such as spontaneous emission, that occur 100 or 1000 times slower. However, the strength of the pulses was taken high enough to transfer substantial probability to an upper medium level and then return it. This allows the development of transient dipole moments in the medium that are large enough to accept information coherences from the pulses, and store them. We discovered how to make proper pulse shape designs that were suitable for retrieval of the information coherences by subsequent pulses, and transfer the information to a location deeper in the medium, or to expel it from the opposite end-face for subsequent detection. The results appear to be suitable for testing by laboratory work with cooled alkali atom vapors such as rubidium or cesium, which are commonly available in Bose-Einstein condensation labs.
